description: From French monogramme, from the Classical Latin adjective monogrammus, from the conjectured Ancient Greek * μονόγραμμος (monógrammos, “outlined”, “drawn with single lines”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A picture drawn in line only, before the colour and/or shading is applied; an outline sketch.

description: Formed as mono- +‎ -gram, by analogy with epigram.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, rare) A sentence consisting of only one line, or an epigram consisting of only one verse, of poetry.

description: The noun derives from the post-Classical Latin monogrammum, itself from the Byzantine Greek μονόγραμμον (monógrammon); compare the French and Middle French monogramme, as well as the Italian monogramma. The verb derives from the noun; compare the earlier adjective monogrammed and the slightly earlier noun monogramming.

entries.meaning: A design or motif composed of one or more letters, often intertwined, used as an identifying mark of an individual or institution.

verbs.description: monogram (third-person singular simple present monograms, present participle monogramming or monograming, simple past and past participle monogrammed or monogramed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To mark something with a monogram.

description: One of the symbols used in either the I Ching divination or the Taixuanjing divination.
